definition:
Let $G$ be a group. A subgroup $H$ of $G$ is said to be *permutable* if
it permutes with all subgroups of $G$, that is, $KH=HK$ for all
$K\leq G$. We sometimes write $H\per G$ to indicate that $H$ is a
permutable subgroup of $G$.

Permutable subgroups were introduced by , who called them *quasinormal*
subgroups.

Normal subgroups are clearly permutable.

Permutable subgroups are ascendant. This is a result of
Stonehewer[@stonehewer], who also showed that in a finitely generated
group, all permutable subgroups are subnormal.

[9]{} Stewart E. Stonehewer, [*Permutable subgroups of infinite
groups*]{}, Math. Z. 125 (1972), 1–16. (This paper is .)
